bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, January 30, 1929

div1.p: Kean relates news of the pension bill and notes the recognition of Agramonte's work in the bill.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, January 30, 1929
div1.opener:
30 January, 1929.
Dr. Aristides Agramonte,
Calle K, Entre 15 Y 17,
Vedado, Habana, Cuba.
My dear Dr. Agramonte:
div1.p:
I hope that the enclosed Act will give you pleasure as
showing that Congress is disposed to give you a somewhat belated
recognition of the indebtedness of this country to you as the only
surviving member of the Reed Board. The bill has not yet passed the
Senate, but I hope may do so if not crowded out by the pressure of
the last days of this Congress which expires on the 4th of March.

General Ireland asked me, if I wrote to you about it, to
express to you his very great pleasure that your great work for humanity
should be recognized by our Government. I know that some months ago when
we were urging this bill he told its supporters that he would have nothing
to do with it unless it recognized your work. The bill as originally
proposed, and as I hoped would pass, provided for a pension of $250.00
a month for you and the three widows of the Board, but this did not seem
to appeal to the Committee whose special interest seemed to lie in the
rewarding of the men who volunteered for the yellow fever experiments.
I will let you know what comes of it in the Senate. Meanwhile with all
good wishes, I am
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN,
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd.,
Editor. JRK/F
